awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Efficient Discriminant Analysis Through Parsimonious Probabilistic Models
awd_abstract_narration:
In the Big-Data era, there is a pressing need to develop more efficient and easy-to-interpret data analysis methods to face the new challenges rising from real life applications, such as cancer diagnosis, brain connectivity network and neuroimaging studies. Besides their intimidating sizes, data sets in such applications demand researchers to understand the intrinsic and complex structure behind them. This research involves new directions in discriminant analysis and classification by exploring state-of-art statistical methods and contemporary computation techniques. The investigators will develop new statistical methods and computational tools to utilize the intrinsic structure of the data, such as high correlation, network structure and tensor/array data structure. The research results will advance the research in statistics, machine learning, text mining, bio-medical research, finance, neuroimaging analysis, among other fields. The research will also be integrated with substantial educational and outreach activities.

In this research, the investigators aim to develop parsimonious probabilistic discriminant analysis models for efficiently analyzing data with intrinsically complicated structures, and for improved estimation of parameters and accuracy in predictions. Three sets of problems will be investigated: (1) parsimonious linear discriminant analysis with envelope, aiming to integrate a nascent technique of envelope modeling with the classical linear discriminant analysis model; (2) simultaneous discriminant analysis and differential network estimation, aiming to develop a novel and unified framework for simultaneously studying differential networks, estimating multiple covariance matrices, and training quadratic discriminant analysis classifier; and (3) sparse tensor discriminant analysis with feature selection, aiming to develop a sparse discriminant analysis method for tensor-valued data that directly uses the tensor-valued features for discriminant analysis, while simultaneously achieving feature selection and preserving interpretable tensor structure.

por.por_cntn:
During the funding period of this NSF project, the PI and Co-PI have developed a new set of parsimonious statistical models with solid methodological and theoretical foundation, efficient computational properties and implementations. The project covered a variety of research topics in discriminant analysis and classification.

Key outcomes including journal publications in premiere statistical and machine learning journals such as 

(i) Zhang, X., Mai, Q. and Zou, H. (2020) , The Maximum Separation Subspace in Sufficient Dimension Reduction with Categorical Response. Journal of Machine Learning Research.

This article developed a novel framework for model-free dimension reduction of data in categorical response studies such as classification and discriminant analysis.

(ii) Pan, Y., Mai, Q. and Zhang, X. (2019) Covariate-adjusted tensor classification in high dimensions. Journal of the American Statistical Association, 114, 1305--1319.

This article developed a classification methods using tensor-variate data (e.g. 3D brian images, videos and imaging streams) and adjusting for additional covariates. 

(iii) Zhang, X. and Mai, Q. (2019), Efficient integration of sufficient dimension reduction and prediction in discriminant analysis. Technometrics, 61, 259--272.

This article proposed a general framework for simultaneously performing the two stages of high-dimensional data analysis, dimension reduction and prediction. Envelope methodology is extended from regression to discriminant analysis and classification in this paper.

As far as broader impact, this NSF project has led to numerous invited conference/colloquia presentations, which have inspired many follow-up research by researchers not only in Statistics but also in other areas such as Biomedical Research, Industrial Engineering, and Neurosciences. The supported research also has facilitated collaborative research in neuroimaging data analysis and open-source software developments. For example, three R packages are published online at CRAN (https://cran.r-project.org/): TRES, CATCH, and TULIP. As a result, practitioners in any area now have additional tools for classifying complex data structures in the forms of tensors, networks, and high-dimensional data. Proposed research has been dissimilated into MS/PhD thesis works of multiple students both inside and outside the PI's home institute. Two new research topic courses, Envelopes and Subspace Learning, has been developed by the PI and taught by the PI in the Fall semester of 2018; Tensor Data Analysis, has been developed by the PI and taught by the PI in the Spring semester of 2020. The new course incorporated the research findings from this NSF project, and was very well received by the students.
